awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Catalyst: Improving Gender and Foreign-Born Equity among STEM Faculty at the University of North Dakota
awd_abstract_narration:
University of North Dakota will implement an ADVANCE Catalyst project to conduct an institutional self-assessment of existing inequalities among its STEM faculty, particularly as experienced by women, racial and ethnic minorities, and foreign-born individuals. These demographic groups constitute over half of the STEM faculty at UND.  Existing differences in salary and tenure and other employment conditions hinder individual, and consequently institutional, advancement. To better understand the complex and important sociocultural processes and policy structures that generate these relative and objective disadvantages among its STEM faculty, UND will use an intersectionality perspective that analyzes how individuals who self-identify with multiple social statuses simultaneously interact within an organization that systematically rank orders social groups, from promotion and tenure to laboratory space. UND will use the information from the institutional self-assessment to design a five-year strategic plan that promotes sustainable equity in its STEM disciplines and may serve as a reference point for non-STEM disciplines.

The two-year project aims to identify the types of, extent of, and reasons for, inequality through a range of methodological techniques, including university analytics, policy analysis, faculty surveys, focus groups, and individual in-depth interviews. The different strategies are advantageous with respect to identifying objective individual differences, organizational arrangements, and intergroup perceptions, all of which aim to shed light on the context of inequality and the mediating sociocultural processes that link micro social identities with systemic advantage or disadvantage. With these results, the broader scope of the project, which is to communicate sustainable strategies for equity in STEM disciplines, may contribute to the advancement of current and future STEM scholars. An additional implication centers on advancing theoretical understanding of dynamic social identities in the workplace, knowledge which may empower diverse individuals and improve research and labor market innovations. 

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions. Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate. ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) ADVANCE program awarded the University of North Dakota (UND) an ADVANCE Catalyst grant in 2021 to conduct an institutional self-assessment regarding equity among STEM faculty, particularly by gender, race, and nationality, and to design a strategic equity plan to address any identified issues. A foundational idea was that the regional STEM workforce would be strengthened by improving faculty advancement and retention, thereby also ensuring a positive impact on STEM education.

The UND ADVANCE Catalyst team consisted of four faculty members from three colleges, one administrator from the Office of Equal Opportunity & Title IX, and one graduate student research assistant. The team subsequently formed a large internal advisory committee comprised of associate vice presidents, associate deans, department chairs, and professors of varying rank from UND and an external advisory committee of three scholars from comparable universities who had experience conducting ADVANCE work at their own institutions.

Over a three-year period, the UND ADVANCE Catalyst team collected population data from the University and the six colleges that house STEM faculty. It also administered an online survey and conducted in-depth individual interviews with STEM faculty, both of which captured a large range of sociodemographic identities, workplace experiences, and faculty opinions.

The research revealed a number of positive outcomes. In brief, the national demographic trends in STEM appear at UND as well, with female faculty, racial and ethnic minoritzed faculty, and international faculty, making up 30 percent, 12 percent, and 29 percent, of the STEM professoriate, respectively. The pathway to leadership as department chair appears to be open, as 41 percent of this administrative position was filled by women. Hiring processes also appear to be open, as 40 percent of new hires were either native-born racial minoritized or foreign-born scholars. The group who experienced the quickest rise in salary was foreign-born women, indicating that the merit raise system is also open. Lastly, male and female STEM faculty received internal university awards at comparable rates and had similar success rates for securing external grants at around 30 percent, or 3 out of 10 attempts.

At the same time, however, there are areas for improvement, as viewed from an intersectionality perspective. The vast majority of the executive administrative positions are filled by native-born white men; foreign-born women begin their careers with the lowest salary; native-born white women average a year longer to attain tenure; evaluation processes have hidden inequities that disadvantage women and foreign-born faculty; research productivity for underrepresented minoritized faculty is constrained by service duties, limited collaboration opportunities, and differential resources; women and minoritized women express higher rates of experiencing bias; and international faculty face unique challenges from limited or inconsistent support with legal immigration processes, adaption to U.S. culture and its education system, bias regarding language-use and accents, and financial constraints from family members' work based on visa status.     

To address these issues, the UND ADVANCE Catalyst team worked with its internal and external advisory committees to write a five-year strategic equity plan that integrated with the University’s new strategic plan called LEADS (Learning, Equity, Affinity, Discovery, and Service). The themes of the five-year strategic equity plan included tenure and promotion processes, perceptions of belonging, research productivity and collaboration, and the importance of department chairs and colleagues, all which primarily fell within the strategic plan pillars of equity, affinity, and discovery. The recommended systemic changes focused on training content for chairs and evaluation committees, regular equity assessments, and research capacity building.

The project also contributed to the intellectual merit of ADVANCE work by empirically corroborating and extending the reach of other ADVANCE projects across the country by finding similar equity issues for women and minorities in institutions of higher education. Adding to foundational knowledge, the project found it critical to include nationality as a primary social category, in addition to the traditional intersections of race, class, and gender, when studying STEM workers. This is vital since the percentage of international scholars working in STEM fields continues to increase.

The project also had many broader impacts, which include professional development, graduate student training, faculty-administration networking, regional partnerships, and knowledge-exchange with national scholars. Lastly, the strategic recommendations and continued ADVANCE work on campus include positive effects for the humanities, creative arts, professional disciplines, and other non-STEM fields, particularly in the areas of tenure and promotion evaluation processes, equity assessments, and department climate. As the changes are made over time, they will also have a beneficial impact on students and their education.
